headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks First Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If you have objections, please disconnect at this time. I'd now like to turn the call
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks First Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If you have objections, please disconnect at this time. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. John Eldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian, and welcome to our conference call for the first quarter of fiscal 2015. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of our executive te
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian, and welcome to our conference call for the first quarter of fiscal 2015. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of our executive team are also on hand to answer questions, following John and Andy's prepared comments. If you have any follow-up questions after the call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6571. A copy of today's press release is available on our website at f5.com.
In addition, you can access an archived version of today's live webcast from the Events Calendar page of our website through April 22, from 4:30 p.m. today until midnight Pacific Time January 22, you can also listen to a telephone replay at (888) 673-3568 or (402) 220-6431.
During today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements that include words such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve uncertainties and risks that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements. Factors that may affect our results are summarized in the quarterly press release, described in detail in our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andy Reinland.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Before I start my prepared remarks, I'll just ask you to be a little patient if I pause, I've been battling a cough, so with that, we'll get underway.Sales in the first quarter of fiscal 2015 reflected the seasonality we normally see at
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Before I start my prepared remarks, I'll just ask you to be a little patient if I pause, I've been battling a cough, so with that, we'll get underway.
Sales in the first quarter of fiscal 2015 reflected the seasonality we normally see at the beginning of our fiscal year. And in general, we saw fewer large deals this quarter compared to previous quarters. As a result, revenue of $462.8 million was in the lower half of our guided range of $460 million to $470 million, reflecting 14% year-over-year growth and down slightly from the fourth quarter of fiscal 2014. 
GAAP EPS was $1.21 per share above our guidance of $1.10 to $1.13 per share. Non-GAAP EPS of $1.55 per share also exceeded our guidance of $1.46 to $1.49 per share. Both GAAP and non-GAAP results include the one-time benefit related to the retroactive reinstatement of the R&D tax credit for 2014, resulting in the benefit to EPS of approximately $0.08 per share on a GAAP basis and $0.07 per share on a non-GAAP basis.
Product revenue of $240.9 million in the first quarter was up 10% year-over-year, down 6% sequentially and accounted for 52% of total revenue. Service revenue of $221.9 million grew 18% year-over-year, 6% sequentially and represented 48% of total revenue. 
Accounting for 56% of the total, revenue from the Americas was up 14% from the first quarter of fiscal 2014. EMEA media, which represented 25% of revenue, grew 20% from the first quarter of last year. APAC accounted for 14% of revenue and grew 9% year-over-year and Japan revenue, representing 5% of total, grew 3% from a year ago. 
Sales to enterprise customers represented 63% of total sales during the quarter. Service providers accounted for 23% and government sales were 13%, including 5% of total sales from U.S. federal. 
In Q1, we had 4 greater than 10% distributors, less con, which represented 17.5% of total revenue, Ingram Micro, which accounted for 16.7%, Avnet, representing 13.9%; and Aero, which accounted for 11.4%. 
Our GAAP gross margin in Q1 was 82.9%. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 84.1%. GAAP operating expenses of $251.1 million were within our target range of $245 million to $253 million. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $222.9 million. GAAP operating margin was 28.6%. Our non-GAAP operating margin was 35.9%. Reflecting the one-time benefit from the retroactive reinstatement of the federal R&D tax credit for 2014, our GAAP effective tax rate for Q1 was 34% and our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 32.3%.
Turning to the balance sheet. Cash flow from operations was $186.4 million. In Q1, we repurchased just under 1.2 million shares of our common stock at an average price of $128.70 for a total of $150 million, ending the quarter with approximately $1.17 billion in cash and investments. With the addition of $750 million authorized by the board for stock buyback at our most recent board meeting, approximately $931 million remains authorized under the share repurchase program. 
DSO at the end of Q1 was 50 days. Inventories were $27.6 million. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $10.3 million. Deferred revenue increased 20% year-over-year to $680.3 million. We ended the quarter with approximately 3,945 employees, an increase of 110 from the prior quarter.
Moving onto Q2 outlook. Based on the strength of our current pipeline, including a return in the number of large deal opportunities, and continued momentum from our key drivers, we anticipate sequential and year-over-year growth in the second quarter of fiscal 2015. Our revenue target for the quarter is $465 million to $475 million. GAAP gross margin is anticipated to be in the 82% to 82.5% range, including approximately $3.5 million of stock-based compensation expense and $2.7 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. Non-GAAP gross margin is expected to be in the 83.5% to 84% range. 
As outlined during our Q1 earnings call, we anticipate an increase in stock compensation in Q2 related to the timing of our annual employee grant. As such for Q2, we anticipate GAAP operating expenses in the range of $255 million to $264 million including approximately $34 million of stock-based compensation expense and $0.5 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. 
For Q2, we are forecasting a GAAP effective tax rate of 38.5% and a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 35.5%. These rates assume no reinstatement of the federal R&D tax credit for 2015. Our GAAP EPS target is $1.07 to $1.10 per share. Our non-GAAP EPS target is $1.48 to $1.51 per share. We plan to increase our headcount in excess of 100 employees in the current quarter and we believe our cash flow from operations will be at or around $110 million reflecting the impact of 2 federal tax payments that we normally incur during our fiscal second quarter.
With that, I will turn the call over to John McAdam.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. Although our revenue came in at the lower end of our guidance and I'll comment on that in a moment, I was pleased with the significant progress we made in all our major initiatives. For example, we had some very
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. Although our revenue came in at the lower end of our guidance and I'll comment on that in a moment, I was pleased with the significant progress we made in all our major initiatives. For example, we had some very strategic security sales wins in the server provider market. We had a very successful launch of Silverline, a key component of our hybrid application services strategy. We added significant functionality to our orchestration and management product, BIG-IQ, which was key to winning the strategic security wins and is also another critical component of our hybrid application services strategy. We also continue to make great progress with our SDN partnerships both in technology and in go to market initiatives. 
From a sales perspective, the majority of the shortfall come from the Americas region where we experienced a larger-than-expected drop in million dollars plus deals in both large enterprise and U.S. federal opportunities. We believe this was a seasonality issue due to a very large number of large wins, closing during our fiscal year end Q4 drive. 
On a more positive note, the pipeline creation rate in Q1 was very strong -- I'm sorry, very strong -- the pipeline for the quarter looks very good. So I understand the sentence there from the original I had. Our Japan business was also below our general forecast, but this was not a major factor overall. Both APAC and EMEA delivered year-over-year sales growth. The EMEA region was the star of the quarter and once again, delivered an excellent performance with solid year-over-year growth. 
Our Services business continued to deliver solid results and excellent profitability along with a healthy increase in deferred revenue, which is now approximately $680 million and should bode well for future business. 
We continue to experience strong momentum with our Good, Better, Best sales motion in Q1 with customer adoption continuing to be very strong in the Best category, highlighting the success we have seen with our security solution. I was also very encouraged by the continuous strong growth of our software revenue, which increased 44% year-over-year. 
The fastest growing area in our software business is our core virtualization ADC. Our software growth is being driven by the increasing customer demand for hybrid solutions that allow greater flexibility and the deployment of application services within and across data centers and into the cloud. Our ability to provide our solutions as virtual software offerings across all the major hybrid providers, combined with our unique orchestration functionality and BIG-IQ is enabling customers to move to software-defined data centers and NSV architectures. 
We're also seeing growth across the entire portfolio of our software module offerings driven by the rapidly increasing recognition that an ADC is the ideal platform to ensure application security. Our Security business continues to be a our largest growth driver with strong sales across the security solution portfolio including ASM, APM and AFM. I already made reference to strategic security sales wins in the service provider market. We won a large ASM Gi firewall sales with a Tier 1 service provider, which resulted in 2 transactions in Q1 being over $1 million each in value. 
I have mentioned several times last year that our BIG-IQ security management and orchestration product road map was being influenced by a Tier 1 service provider in North America. This initiative has proved to be very successful and we are now starting to see some real momentum globally with our Gi firewall solutions and we believe it can be a strong growth driver in fiscal 2015 and beyond. 
Overall, we had a solid quarter in the service provider market in Q1. We had several very strategic wins over and above the Gi firewall deals. For example, we won a large 2 million plus software-only NSV application with another Tier 1 server provider in North America. Our consolidation strategy and focus on security, NSV, Gi 1 services and LTE applications is resonating well with the service provider as we offer them the opportunity to reduce OpEx while monetizing the added value services with our unique application and subscriber awareness. 
We continue to see strong sales of Cisco Asia placement last quarter. As we have seen in previous quarters, customers continue to take the opportunity to add additional functionality, for example, our ASM security module when the implement in USI Solutions. We have created a self-service web portal for ACE migrations, which complements a significant experience and consulting expertise and increases our competitive advantage. 
Also we intend to stamp up our market initiatives on ACE opportunities starting this quarter to take advantage of our current momentum and experience a transitioning ACE customers to F5 ADC solutions. We have experienced a very positive reaction to the launch of our Silverline hybrid application services strategy from our sales force, partners and customers. The initial launch included our subscription base DDoS servers and our anti-malware and phishing protection service. These cloud-based offerings deliver flexible, best-in-class services and offer a hybrid model complementing F5 on-premise product and solutions. We have already seen some excellent orders for both our subscription based DDoS servers and anti-malware solutions. We're applying to increase support the portfolio of cloud-based subscription services, starting with the ASM solution in the next few months. 
From a product perspective, we have a host of new functionality and new products on our current road map. We recently released a new high end, 2U platform, the BIG-IP 12,000. This platform extends performance of our content thousand platform by 25%, increases SSL performance by 600% and more than doubles the number of high-performance vCMP instances. The SSL performance is really important given the SSL trend that we're seeing. 
In the near future, we'll be enhancing our management and orchestration capabilities with BIG-IQ release 4.5. This release will include significant enhancements for our data center security products AFM and ASM, as well as comprehensive support for our SDN ecosystem to provide application management capabilities with an SDN-enabled network. The BIG-IQ Clive module now supports SDN control integration with Cisco intake, VMware NSX, Alcatel Mirage, Microsoft SCVM and OpenStack. We will also be adding a new module BIG-IQ ADC. BIG-IQ ADC provides centralized, fine-grained application management across cloud-based SDN and traditional network infrastructure. 
The drivers of our business remain robust and I expect momentum to build in this coming quarter and continue into the second half of the year. Our hybrid application services based on our centers architecture and Silverline cloud services is resonating really well with our customers and partners. This strategy, combined with the strength of our partner ecosystems in areas like SDN, provide F5 with an opportunity to play a very strategic role while customers continue to strive for competitive advantage and maximum agility by moving to new technology architectures. 
Also our portfolio of application products and cloud services continues to expand aggressively, which in turn significantly expands our addressable market and increases the type of revenue streams available to our sales force and partner channel. 
As far as the outlook is concerned, Andy indicated that we expect both sequential and year-over-year growth this quarter. As I mentioned earlier, our business pipeline create rate was very strong in Q1, up significantly over the previous year and a pipeline of business this quarter looks very strong. In particular, we have seen a large increase in the number of large deals in the pipeline. We continue to plan for growth in the business by investing ahead current and infrastructure moving forward, whilst deliver world-class operating margins. 
I continue to feel very positive about future business prospects for F5. I believe that our existing product portfolio, our hybrid application services strategy and our product road map are not only in line with customer and market trends, but are also key to enabling these trends. In conclusion, I'd like to thank the entire F5 team of partners and customers for their support last quarter and with that, we'll hand the call over to Q&A.

componenttextpreview: On the revenue side, the jump -- we've seen for a number of years, our clients go for coterminous contracts so their first of January and the first of July. This quarter, obviously ended with the first of January, we had a very strong push and we are able
componenttext: On the revenue side, the jump -- we've seen for a number of years, our clients go for coterminous contracts so their first of January and the first of July. This quarter, obviously ended with the first of January, we had a very strong push and we are able to recognize more revenue within the quarter and as part of that push, we build out the deferred revenue.

componenttextpreview: Because contracts end for January 1, you're trying to get them to renewal before that date, and because they're coterminous, some of the units have not been on support for 2, 3 or 4 months, so we get some backdated revenue in there at the same time.

Is this a function of some of the new products, some of the bundling? Is this something that we should think about more going forward in terms of having these larger deals in the mix?

componenttextpreview: No, we don't think so. I mean if you look at last fiscal year, 2014, we saw a pretty significant rebound in the large million-dollar-plus deals every single quarter. Obviously, we saw a blip in our Q1 ending in December, but having said that, we expect to
componenttext: No, we don't think so. I mean if you look at last fiscal year, 2014, we saw a pretty significant rebound in the large million-dollar-plus deals every single quarter. Obviously, we saw a blip in our Q1 ending in December, but having said that, we expect to see that rebound given what we're looking at in terms of some of some of the slipped and B, the creation rate that we've done over -- in Q1, which was pretty solid. So we expect the million dollar numbers to come strong again in the coming quarter.

componenttextpreview: The pipeline in sales doesn't shrink. In fact, when you start to see deals slip, you actually see the pipeline create. What we saw was the 5 [ph] pipeline deals that we were expecting to close not quite coming in and then slipping out into the next quarte
componenttext: The pipeline in sales doesn't shrink. In fact, when you start to see deals slip, you actually see the pipeline create. What we saw was the 5 [ph] pipeline deals that we were expecting to close not quite coming in and then slipping out into the next quarter. And that tends to happen towards the end.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, in the past, some of the quarters were in the million-dollar deals have gone down. You've talked about that being an indicator of macro, so -- but this time, were you residing in seasonality, so if you could talk about that, why are you convinced th
componenttext: John, in the past, some of the quarters were in the million-dollar deals have gone down. You've talked about that being an indicator of macro, so -- but this time, were you residing in seasonality, so if you could talk about that, why are you convinced there? And then secondly, is there an element of needing a little bit of a reset here, coming in at a bit lower? Is there any element here of this transition to kind of an on-demand software and virtual model? Does that play any part in the miss in the quarter?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, they were in the guidance in the quarter, remember. I know that's not good because we tend to beat, just to be clear. On the first part, you're absolutely right. If you go back to 2013 when we saw a fairly precipitous drop in million-dollar deals,
componenttext: Right, they were in the guidance in the quarter, remember. I know that's not good because we tend to beat, just to be clear. On the first part, you're absolutely right. If you go back to 2013 when we saw a fairly precipitous drop in million-dollar deals, we did talk about macro and a fair to macro more than once in that case, and that's because when we look to that, the forward-looking pipeline was anything as strong as it's looking today. So we're seeing -- this is a different scenario in our opinion. We really believe this is more seasonality-linked than anything and a piece of fair as well, was clearly some still some lack of transparency in fed that we know in budget, hopefully, that will improve. They were the 2 things that we see, but as we look forward, we see a stronger pipeline with a higher percentage of factoring in that pipeline, hence, as not referring to macro. And the second question was the transition from a software. Now we don't see that. In fact, interestingly enough, these software deals that we see from a virtualization perspective or from an NFV perspective, these are big. I mean these are actually pretty big deals as customers are horizontally scaling across their application and therefore, buying a lot of instances of virtualization, so maybe overtime, we'll see that, but I don't believe that was an indicator this quarter.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just have one follow-up. With these large virtualization deals though, is there any change in the competitive landscape? Any new competitors that you don't traditionally see competing for these deals?
componenttext: I just have one follow-up. With these large virtualization deals though, is there any change in the competitive landscape? Any new competitors that you don't traditionally see competing for these deals?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Manny. No, absolutely not. I mean what we're seeing is we're basically seeing the need depending on the enterprise or service provider, of course, customers who want to go to software-only architectures. In general, there is some newer co
componenttext: Michael, this is Manny. No, absolutely not. I mean what we're seeing is we're basically seeing the need depending on the enterprise or service provider, of course, customers who want to go to software-only architectures. In general, there is some newer competitors sometimes in the market, but it tends to be the same cost competitors who have offered a hardware version of the software version.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the large deals again, I guess I'm curious because there's so many things happening between hardware moving to also support virtual additions, tying with SDN, your product coming more software. Again, how much of this might be more product specific,
componenttext: So on the large deals again, I guess I'm curious because there's so many things happening between hardware moving to also support virtual additions, tying with SDN, your product coming more software. Again, how much of this might be more product specific, the deals getting more complex? It does seem like you had a lot of new technology to think about and Cisco did have some weakness in its billings for the October-quarter, guys like VMware also has some choppy booking, so I'm curious as you look at the complexity of products can you really attribute any of that to the complexity?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really, I don't think we can. I just don't think we can. It's based on the deals that are there, we understand they are very similar to what they were in Q4 where we had a massive push with large deals and we don't see any change in that landscape whatsoe
componenttext: Really, I don't think we can. I just don't think we can. It's based on the deals that are there, we understand they are very similar to what they were in Q4 where we had a massive push with large deals and we don't see any change in that landscape whatsoever.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And one of the factors that impacts growth rate was you refreshed all of your product lines a little over a year ago. So last year, we enjoyed quite a bit of acceleration growth rate, you're coming off of tough comps. Are you seeing any impact from just t
componenttext: And one of the factors that impacts growth rate was you refreshed all of your product lines a little over a year ago. So last year, we enjoyed quite a bit of acceleration growth rate, you're coming off of tough comps. Are you seeing any impact from just the pent-up demand maybe that was created from the product cycle and just things slowing down after people went ahead and did the refreshers. Any thoughts on that as a driver?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: We saw a bit of that and if you look at the drivers and its probably what again, just to summarize, but obviously product refresh, we talked about there. It was a low hanging fruit in the beginning, it's not quite there at the moment probably. Do we still
componenttext: We saw a bit of that and if you look at the drivers and its probably what again, just to summarize, but obviously product refresh, we talked about there. It was a low hanging fruit in the beginning, it's not quite there at the moment probably. Do we still have a very large installed base of products that we can refresh? Absolutely. So I think does that, area obviously the 1,200 with SSL capability, I think is clearly -- is 1 point product but it's excess is our capability, that's a pretty good opportunity to refresh as well. But the big drivers are security was a firewall that we talked about, ASM with the solution or DDoS on Prem and off premise and then the service provider, we feel very good about the drivers there and NSV from a security perspective, CCP optimization. We still feel good about ACE, I mentioned about what we're going to do there and the SDN partnerships and in general, the cloud movement I think is a growth possibility for us. So product refresh, probably to some degree, but we still think there's a big opportunity there.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, last question. Given the growth in pipeline, partly the new creation as well as deals slipping, with your guidance, that product growth rate is continued to decelerate because somewhere near your high single digits when you look at your guidance, ho
componenttext: Okay, last question. Given the growth in pipeline, partly the new creation as well as deals slipping, with your guidance, that product growth rate is continued to decelerate because somewhere near your high single digits when you look at your guidance, how do you get this back up and why isn't the guidance for the March-quarter better just given the buildup of the million-dollar plus projects?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Historically, March-quarter, you need to be careful with that because it's always the beginning of a financial year for a lot of companies. We are assuming, I hope relatively conservative close rates and the fact of the pipeline and we'll see where that takes us.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Next question Subu Subrahmanyan, group.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First on the service provider side, if you could talk about the CapEx backdrop, you certainly have some wins and share gain opportunities. So how do you think about the service provider vertical for this year? Do you expect it to grow as a
componenttext: Two questions. First on the service provider side, if you could talk about the CapEx backdrop, you certainly have some wins and share gain opportunities. So how do you think about the service provider vertical for this year? Do you expect it to grow as a percentage of revenues in fiscal '14, and then on the virtualization side, certainly, here you that the deals are large, but if you do a comparison, the architectural changes, if you had sold all the hardware instances as you might have a few years ago versus a mix of hardware and software, what that is doing to the overall dollar value of the deals and also the profitability of the deals, that would be helpful.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Manny. Let me answer the service provider. On the service provider, we have 4 major drivers that I think we were talking about, they were definitely in John's prepared comments, which is consolidation across the board from a service provider point
componenttext: This is Manny. Let me answer the service provider. On the service provider, we have 4 major drivers that I think we were talking about, they were definitely in John's prepared comments, which is consolidation across the board from a service provider point of view and that's consolidation of services, predominantly traffic steering services, carrier grid map services and some other services that were consolidated inside that environment. That reduces CapEx really for many of the operators out there, because they're going from multi vendors to a single vendor. Second major driver we have is security, which is also something we could overlay on that same footprint. Again from a consolidation point of view, but we call it out as a separate driver because it's just the impact from the size associated with that, but there is NFV and the NFV footprints that we're seeing out there, which are still early proof of concepts to some degree and we are in various proof of concepts across the world. We're starting to see some of those pan out and that's what happened this past quarter and why we have a big bump also in our software sales. And the last is the LTE or the mobility movement going to 4G networks, which we've been seeding in the customer environment for the last 2 years and we're starting to see there also from a driver perspective that these networks get deployed, get accepted, usage volume goes up, new devices are being enabled, meaning additional mobile handsets but also new devices from the perspective of the Internet of Things that we're going to see additional software license there. So those are predominantly the 4 major drivers and those are usually either tackling the CapEx volume from a consolidation point of view or the monetization line from something along the perspective of LTE and being able to bring on new services to the market.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the virtualization side of things, which I think is very similar to that, so a similar question, which was basically -- first of all, these are still smaller numbers. I mean this is still a relatively small market versus overall ADC market, but the
componenttext: And on the virtualization side of things, which I think is very similar to that, so a similar question, which was basically -- first of all, these are still smaller numbers. I mean this is still a relatively small market versus overall ADC market, but the deals that we're seeing are pretty large in nature and we need to market exactly to see the difference that was all hardware versus all software, I'm not sure we're seeing that much difference, quite frankly. So I don't think if you're looking for is that the factor and what happened in terms of bringing us to the low-end of the range? We don't think so.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to add one more comment, Manny again, on the software side that we see, is we see an expansion of the application needs in the market segment. What I mean by that is historically, a handful of applications in the typical enterprise and service pr
componenttext: And just to add one more comment, Manny again, on the software side that we see, is we see an expansion of the application needs in the market segment. What I mean by that is historically, a handful of applications in the typical enterprise and service provider got the ADC services because it was harder to deploy much more complex. As we move toward a much more software-based architectures, what you see is a broader set of applications getting these services because it's easier to deploy those services in the environment, so it's actually to a large degree, an expansion in the market.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Next question from Brent Bracelin, Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Two quick follow-ups if I could. On the million-dollar deals, if you look at across the broader enterprise, we've actually seen a trend towards and you do as well, up until this quarter, an increasing number of larger deals that closed. Do you think what you saw in December was company-specific or do you think there were other factors here at play and I have one more.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a really hard one, we don't know the answer to that, Brett. We just don't know the answer. I think as more companies announced and there may be some more news on that, I certainly wouldn't call out and that's why we're not calling out this macro qu
componenttext: That's a really hard one, we don't know the answer to that, Brett. We just don't know the answer. I think as more companies announced and there may be some more news on that, I certainly wouldn't call out and that's why we're not calling out this macro quite frankly. The other side of the coin is that create rate that we had is probably the biggest create rate we've seen, if not the biggest and certainly one of the biggest and I'm talking about large deals, so time will tell in terms of whether it's a bigger issue or not.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The follow-up question is back to software and as we kind of compare contrast the software growth rate versus your reported product growth rate, it was 44% software growth rate this quarter versus 10% product growth. If I look at your Analyst Day, you tal
componenttext: The follow-up question is back to software and as we kind of compare contrast the software growth rate versus your reported product growth rate, it was 44% software growth rate this quarter versus 10% product growth. If I look at your Analyst Day, you talked about I think 41% security software growth rate versus 17% product growth rate, so there's a widening gap there between kind of the growth in software versus product appliance overall. Why shouldn't we expect slightly more tempered growth going forward with a mix shift to software, given the trends over the last couple of quarters. And frankly now, given some of the announcements around new products, where you're going to be pricing those products on a subscription basis.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean I think if you take a medium to longer term view, that's correct. That's absolutely correct, you're going to see us selling more and more software, we've done that now. We pushed the sales force to do that, it's our competitive edge. It's obviously
componenttext: I mean I think if you take a medium to longer term view, that's correct. That's absolutely correct, you're going to see us selling more and more software, we've done that now. We pushed the sales force to do that, it's our competitive edge. It's obviously very, very profitable. We think when great shape in terms of our BIG-IQ orchestration for managing software across clouds and clouds across data centers, et cetera, so you will see that. I don't think it's going to be a complete revolutionary process, I think it's going to be evolutionary. If you look at the -- it's interesting, if you look at the Gi firewall opportunities, the software content is of course, very significant, but so is actually the hardware content because it needs to cope with a significant amount of traffic either on the DDoS side of things or just in pure mobile traffic firewall protection, so I think the trends are going to be there, but to pay for 1 quarter from Q4 to Q1 and say that's a trend, I think would be very dangerous. We don't believe that.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Next question James Faucette Morgan Stanley.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered, so I wanted to dig a little bit just around more of the edges, if you will. First, wondering if you can talk a little bit about what you think was happening in Japan and APAC, you called out the Japan was a little
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered, so I wanted to dig a little bit just around more of the edges, if you will. First, wondering if you can talk a little bit about what you think was happening in Japan and APAC, you called out the Japan was a little bit below your forecast. And then conversely, what you think was going right in EMEA in particular with the weakness of the euro. It seems like that could have been subject to a little more weakness than what you saw and I guess as a follow-up to that, is there going to be a point in which you feel like you have to reprice products for that market and how should we take that into account?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start with EMEA, because it's the easier one. EMEA, in my opinion is tremendous execution. We have great management there. We've been covering it really well, selling big deals, they're selling our software capabilities. Internally, always had a ve
componenttext: Let me start with EMEA, because it's the easier one. EMEA, in my opinion is tremendous execution. We have great management there. We've been covering it really well, selling big deals, they're selling our software capabilities. Internally, always had a very strong leading toward security and they're very early days in fact, led that March. So I think we're talking execution and I think, in Japan is different. Japan is still tend to go for smaller type products, we're not quite as competitive there. We've been spending a lot of time trying to get that direct business up and direct touch I should say, still with partners but direct touch, we made some progress, but it's pretty slow. And generally, the economy is quite slow. And in APAC, we've been doing some changes, some management changes. We actually feel good about the trajectory APAC is on.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So back to your -- looking forward is, do you feel like you're going through -- I know for a lot of other vendors, they've had to or they've asked their resellers and borrowers to absorb at least some of the impact of the depreciating euro, but wondering
componenttext: So back to your -- looking forward is, do you feel like you're going through -- I know for a lot of other vendors, they've had to or they've asked their resellers and borrowers to absorb at least some of the impact of the depreciating euro, but wondering if you feel like you're going to have to change pricing into that market? And how we should take that into account or are you going to be able to basically put through effectively price increases to those customers?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Historically, when we've seen fluctuations in currency because we [indiscernible] U.S. dollars principally in EMEA, and we've been able to navigate that, working with the partners and the resellers conversely they benefited at times when it's gone the oth
componenttext: Historically, when we've seen fluctuations in currency because we [indiscernible] U.S. dollars principally in EMEA, and we've been able to navigate that, working with the partners and the resellers conversely they benefited at times when it's gone the other way, so I'm not sure we would necessarily do a change in price strategy from that, but we will as we execute through the quarter, take that into consideration as we look at deals and work with the partners and resellers to close business.

componenttext: Can we go back to the service provider for a minute and any of the NSV, are you seeing, just to give more color around this, you said proof of concepts, have you deployed -- has there been any deployments within NST, et cetera and then the follow-on question has to do with the enterprise spending, so, first, if we could have some color with NSC with carriers.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Manny. So yes, on the NSV side, we have close to 2,000 proof of concepts throughout the world, just to give you the size of the magnitude of the transaction, and those are across all of the theaters. The wins that we've recently seen, which vary acro
componenttext: It's Manny. So yes, on the NSV side, we have close to 2,000 proof of concepts throughout the world, just to give you the size of the magnitude of the transaction, and those are across all of the theaters. The wins that we've recently seen, which vary across 2 of the theaters are predominantly security-related wins where we are taking our security products from a software perspective and introducing them inside that environment. Obviously, they expand the on-security and also our traffic steering, CGNAT type of deployments. But they're going into the concept of beginning to consolidate services for on a virtual EPC and a lot of the providers are moving in that direction fairly quickly. So we're doing well in that environment, we're integrating our stack with lots of different SDN providers in the market segment and that gives us a lot of flexibility to work with those operators. So it's early days, but we're seeing a lot of good momentum, a lot of good traction and proof of concepts are going favorable.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll try to speak too in here, if I could. First on the Good, Better, Best, just love an update there. You've talked a little bit in the past, we know the Best option is doing well. If you can talk a little bit about the metrics there, how broadly is it t
componenttext: I'll try to speak too in here, if I could. First on the Good, Better, Best, just love an update there. You've talked a little bit in the past, we know the Best option is doing well. If you can talk a little bit about the metrics there, how broadly is it through the sales force now? Is it fully everywhere? How many deals is it influencing? Are we still seeing growth from that? Are we starting to reach a more full penetration? And then the second one, John, I think you mentioned something about factoring the large deals a little bit more into next quarter, I guess part of that is conservatism, but I'm just curious if given the uncertain macro, are you also as a team, factoring in the rest of the business to sub $100 million deals more than normal as well in the guidance.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the Good, Better, Best, the metrics are very similar. I mentioned it's still gravitating greatly towards Better, Best and in fact, I think this quarter we're even higher in terms of our percentage towards Best. And from a -- if you look at where we
componenttext: So on the Good, Better, Best, the metrics are very similar. I mentioned it's still gravitating greatly towards Better, Best and in fact, I think this quarter we're even higher in terms of our percentage towards Best. And from a -- if you look at where we are in the process, North America were [indiscernible] of the shoots and they've been pretty aggressive in selling that. We started then a couple of quarters later on when the quarter -- 1 to 2 quarters later, seeing EMEA starting, but they've got more room to do to catch-up. And then APAC and Japan in particular, tend to lag a little bit with pricing changes there, so we expect that to start to rev up in the future as well. And in terms of the factoring, yes, actually when we do have factoring, we don't tend to just factor by size of deal. We look at the overall factor. We look at the pipeline and then we look at a close rate expectations, so that tends to run rates across the low deals right up to the high deals as well.

componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks First Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If you have objections, please disconnect at this time. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. John Eldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian, and welcome to our conference call for the first quarter of fiscal 2015. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of our executive te
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian, and welcome to our conference call for the first quarter of fiscal 2015. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of our executive team are also on hand to answer questions, following John and Andy's prepared comments. If you have any follow-up questions after the call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6571. 
A copy of today's press release is available on our website at f5.com.  In addition, you can access an archived version of today's live webcast from the Events Calendar page of our website through April 22, from 4:30 p.m. today until midnight Pacific Time, January 22, you can also listen to a telephone replay at (888) 673-3568 or (402) 220-6431.
During today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements that include words such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve uncertainties and risks that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements. Factors that may affect our results are summarized in our quarterly release, described in detail in our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andy Reinland.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Before I start my prepared remarks, I'll just ask you to be a little patient if I pause. I've been battling a cough. So with that, we'll get underway.Sales in the first quarter of fiscal 2015 reflected the seasonality we normally see at
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Before I start my prepared remarks, I'll just ask you to be a little patient if I pause. I've been battling a cough. So with that, we'll get underway.
Sales in the first quarter of fiscal 2015 reflected the seasonality we normally see at the beginning of our fiscal year. And in general, we saw fewer large deals this quarter compared to previous quarters. As a result, revenue of $462.8 million was in the lower half of our guided range of $460 million to $470 million, reflecting 14% year-over-year growth and down slightly from the fourth quarter of fiscal 2014. 
GAAP EPS was $1.21 per share above our guidance of $1.10 to $1.13 per share. Non-GAAP EPS of $1.55 per share also exceeded our guidance of $1.46 to $1.49 per share. Both GAAP and non-GAAP results include a onetime benefit related to the retroactive reinstatement of the R&D tax credit for 2014, resulting in a benefit to EPS of approximately $0.08 per share on a GAAP basis and $0.07 per share on a non-GAAP basis.
Product revenue of $240.9 million in the first quarter was up 10% year-over-year, down 6% sequentially and accounted for 52% of total revenue. Service revenue of $221.9 million grew 18% year-over-year, 6% sequentially and represented 48% of total revenue. 
Accounting for 56% of the total, revenue from the Americas was up 14% from the first quarter of fiscal 2014. EMEA, which represented 25% of revenue, grew 20% from the first quarter of last year. APAC accounted for 14% of revenue and grew 9% year-over-year. And Japan revenue, representing 5% of total, grew 3% from a year ago. 
Sales to enterprise customers represented 63% of total sales during the quarter. Service providers accounted for 23%, and government sales were 13%, including 5% of total sales from U.S. federal. 
In Q1, we had 4 greater than 10% distributors: Westcon, which represented 17.5% of total revenue, Ingram Micro, which accounted for 16.7%, Avnet, representing 13.9%; and Arrow, which accounted for 11.4%. 
Our GAAP gross margin in Q1 was 82.9%. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 84.1%. 
GAAP operating expenses of $251.1 million were within our target range of $245 million to $253 million. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $222.9 million. 
GAAP operating margin was 28.6%. Our non-GAAP operating margin was 35.9%. Reflecting the onetime benefit from the retroactive reinstatement of the federal R&D tax credit for 2014, our GAAP effective tax rate for Q1 was 34% and our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 32.3%.
Turning to the balance sheet. Cash flow from operations was $186.4 million. In Q1, we repurchased just under 1.2 million shares of our common stock at an average price of $128.70 for a total of $150 million, ending the quarter with approximately $1.17 billion in cash and investments. With the addition of $750 million authorized by the board for stock buyback at our most recent board meeting, approximately $931 million remains authorized under the share repurchase program. 
DSO at the end of Q1 was 50 days. Inventories were $27.6 million. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $10.3 million. Deferred revenue increased 20% year-over-year to $680.3 million. We ended the quarter with approximately 3,945 employees, an increase of 110 from the prior quarter.
Moving onto Q2 outlook. Based on the strength of our current pipeline, including a return in the number of large deal opportunities, and continued momentum from our key drivers, we anticipate sequential and year-over-year growth in the second quarter of fiscal 2015. Our revenue target for the quarter is $465 million to $475 million. GAAP gross margin is anticipated to be in the 82% to 82.5% range, including approximately $3.5 million of stock-based compensation expense and $2.7 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. Non-GAAP gross margin is expected to be in the 83.5% to 84% range. 
As outlined during our Q1 earnings call, we anticipate an increase in stock compensation in Q2 related to the timing of our annual employee grant. As such for Q2, we anticipate GAAP operating expenses in the range of $255 million to $264 million including approximately $34 million of stock-based compensation expense and $0.5 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. 
For Q2, we are forecasting a GAAP effective tax rate of 38.5% and a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 35.5%. These rates assume no reinstatement of the federal R&D tax credit for 2015. Our GAAP EPS target is $1.07 to $1.10 per share. Our non-GAAP EPS target is $1.48 to $1.51 per share. We plan to increase our headcount in excess of 100 employees in the current quarter and we believe our cash flow from operations will be at or around $110 million reflecting the impact of 2 federal tax payments that we normally incur during our fiscal second quarter.
With that, I will turn the call over to John McAdam.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. Although our revenue came in at the lower end of our guidance, and I'll comment on that in a moment, I was pleased with the significant progress we made in all our major initiatives. For example, we had some ver
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. Although our revenue came in at the lower end of our guidance, and I'll comment on that in a moment, I was pleased with the significant progress we made in all our major initiatives. For example, we had some very strategic security sales wins in the server provider market. We had a very successful launch of Silverline, a key component of our hybrid application services strategy. We added significant functionality to our orchestration and management product, BIG-IQ, which was key to winning the strategic security wins and is also another critical component of our hybrid application services strategy. We also continue to make great progress with our SDN partnerships both in technology and in go-to-market initiatives. 
From a sales perspective, the majority of the shortfall come from the Americas region, where we experienced a larger-than-expected drop in million-dollar-plus deals in both large enterprise and U.S. federal opportunities. We believe this was a seasonality issue due to a very large number of large wins closing during our fiscal year end Q4 drive. 
On a more positive note, the pipeline creation rate in Q1 was very strong -- I'm sorry, very strong -- the pipeline for the quarter looks very, very good. Sorry, I misspoke our sentence there from the original I had. Our Japan business was also below our general forecast, but this was not a major factor overall. Both APAC and EMEA delivered year-over-year sales growth. The EMEA region was the star of the quarter and once again delivered an excellent performance with solid year-over-year growth. 
 
Our Services business continued to deliver solid results and excellent profitability along with a healthy increase in deferred revenue, which is now approximately $680 million and should bode well for future business. 
We continue to experience strong momentum with our Good, Better, Best sales motion in Q1, with customer adoption continuing to be very strong in the Best category, highlighting the success we have seen with our security solutions. I was also very encouraged by the continuous strong growth of our software revenue, which increased 44% year-over-year. 
The fastest growing area in our software business is our core virtualization ADC. Our software growth is being driven by the increasing customer demand for hybrid solutions that allow greater flexibility in the deployment of application services within and across data centers and into the cloud. Our ability to provide our solutions as virtual software-only offerings across all the major hybrid providers, combined with our unique orchestration functionality and BIG-IQ, is enabling customers to move to software-defined data centers and NFV architectures. 
We're also seeing growth across the entire portfolio of our software module offerings driven by the rapidly increasing recognition that an ADC is the ideal platform to ensure application security. Our Security business continues to be our largest growth driver with strong sales across the security solution portfolio including ASM, APM and AFM. I already made reference to the strategic security sales wins in the service provider market. We won a large ASM Gi firewall sales with a Tier 1 service provider, which resulted in 2 transactions in Q1 being over $1 million each in value. 
I have mentioned several times last year that our BIG-IQ security management and orchestration product road map was being influenced by a Tier 1 service provider in North America. This initiative has proved to be very successful, and we are now starting to see some real momentum globally with our Gi firewall solution and we believe it can be a strong growth driver in fiscal 2015 and beyond. 
Overall, we had a solid quarter in the service provider market in Q1. We had several very strategic wins over and above the Gi firewall deals. For example, we won a large 2 million plus software-only NFV application with another Tier 1 server provider in North America. Our consolidation strategy and focus on security, NFV, Gi  won [ph] services and LTE application is resonating well with the service provider as we offer them the opportunity to reduce OpEx while monetizing their added value services with our unique application and subscriber awareness. 
We continue to see strong sales of Cisco ACE placements last quarter. As we have seen in previous quarters, customers continue to take the opportunity to add additional functionality, for example, our ASM and/or AFM security module, when they implement the new F5 solutions. We have created a self-service web portal for ACE migrations, which complements our significant experience and consulting expertise and increases our competitive advantage. 
Also we intend to step up our market initiatives on the ACE opportunities starting this quarter to take advantage of our current momentum and our experience in transitioning ACE customers to F5 ADC solutions. 
We have experienced a very positive reaction to the launch of our Silverline hybrid application services strategy from our sales force, partners and customers. The initial launch included our subscription-based DDoS servers and our anti-malware and phishing protection service. These cloud-based offerings deliver flexible, best-in-class services and offer a hybrid model complementing F5 on-premise product and solutions. We have already seen some excellent orders for both our subscription-based DDoS servers and anti-malware solutions. We're applying to increase the portfolio of cloud-based subscription services, starting with our WAP ASM solution in the next few months. 
From a product perspective, we have a host of new functionality and new products on our current roadmap. We recently released a new high-end 2U platform, the BIG-IP 12000. This platform extends performance of our current 10000 platform by 25%, increases SSL performance by 600% and more than doubles the number of high-performanced vCMP instances. The SSL performance is really important, given that SSL [ph] trend that we're seeing. 
In the near future, we will be enhancing our management and orchestration capabilities with BIG-IQ release 4.5. This release will include significant enhancements for our data center security products, AFM and ASM, as well as comprehensive support for our SDN ecosystem to provide application management capabilities with an SDN-enabled network. The BIG-IQ Cloud module now supports SDN controller integration with Cisco Atech [ph], VMware NSX, Alcatel Mirage, Microsoft SCVMM and OpenStack. We will also be adding a new module, BIG-IQ ADC. BIG-IQ ADC provides centralized, fine-grained application management across cloud-based SDN and traditional network infrastructure. 
The drivers of our business remain robust, and I expect momentum to build in this coming quarter and continue into the second half of the year. Our hybrid application services based on our Synthesis architecture and Silverline cloud services is resonating really well with our customers and partners. This strategy, combined with the strength of our partner ecosystems in areas like SDN, provide F5 with an opportunity to play a very strategic role while customers continue to strive for competitive advantage and maximum agility by moving to new technology architectures. 
Also, our portfolio of application products and cloud services continues to expand aggressively, which in turn significantly expands our addressable market and increases the type of revenue streams available to our sales force and partner channel. 
As far as the outlook is concerned, Andy indicated that we expect both sequential and year-over-year growth this quarter. As I mentioned earlier, our business pipeline create rate was very strong in Q1, up significantly over the previous year and the pipeline of business this quarter looks very strong. In particular, we have seen a large increase in the number of large deals in the pipeline. We continue to plan for growth in the business by investing in headcount and infrastructure moving forward, whilst deliver world-class operating margins. 
I continue to feel very positive of our future business prospects for F5. I believe that our existing product portfolio, our hybrid application services strategy and our product roadmap are not only in line with customer and market trends, but are also key to enabling these trends. 
In conclusion, I'd like to thank the entire F5 team of partners and customers for their support last quarter. And with that, we'll hand the call over to Q&A.

componenttext: No, we don't think so. I mean, if you look at last fiscal year, 2014, we saw a pretty significant rebound in the large million-dollar-plus deals every single quarter. componenttext: John, in the past, in some of the quarters when the million-dollar deals have gone down, you've talked about that being an indicator of macro, so -- but this time, what you're really just saying is seasonality. So if you could talk about that, why you're convinced there. And then secondly, is there an element of needing a little bit of a reset here, coming in at a bit lower? Is there any element here of this transition to kind of an on-demand software and virtual model? Did that play any part in the miss in the quarter?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. By the way, they were in the guidance in the quarter, remember. I know that's not good because we tend to beat, just to be clear. On the first part, you're absolutely right. If you go back to 2013 when we saw a fairly precipitous drop in million-do
componenttext: Right. By the way, they were in the guidance in the quarter, remember. I know that's not good because we tend to beat, just to be clear. On the first part, you're absolutely right. If you go back to 2013 when we saw a fairly precipitous drop in million-dollar deals, we did talk about macro and refer to macro more than once in that case. And that's because when we looked to that, the forward-looking pipeline was anything as strong as it's looking today. So we're seeing -- this is a different scenario, in our opinion. We really believe this was more seasonality-linked than anything. And a piece of Fed as well, where there's clearly still some lack of transparency in the Fed. When we know the budget, hopefully, that will improve. They were the 2 things that we see. But as we look forward, we see a stronger pipeline with a higher percentage of factoring in that pipeline. Hence, I was not referring to macro. And sorry, and the second question was -- oh yes, the transition from software. Now we don't see that. In fact, interestingly enough, these software deals that we see from a virtualization perspective or from an NFV perspective, these are big. I mean, these are actually pretty big deals as customers are horizontally scaling across their application and therefore, buying a lot of instances of their virtualization. So maybe overtime, we'll see that. But I don't believe that was an indicator this quarter.

componenttext: So on the large deals again, I guess I'm curious because there's so many things happening between hardware moving to also support virtual additions, tying with SDN, your products becoming more softer. Again, how much of this might be more product specific, the deals getting more complex? It does seem like you had a lot of new technology to think about and Cisco did have some weakness in its billings for the October quarter. Guys like VMware also had some choppy booking. So I'm curious, as you look at the complexity of products, can you really attribute any of that to the complexity?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really, I don't think we can. And I just don't think we can. It's based on the deals that are there. We understand them. They're very similar to what they were in Q4, where we had a massive push with large deals. And then we don't see any change in that l
componenttext: Really, I don't think we can. And I just don't think we can. It's based on the deals that are there. We understand them. They're very similar to what they were in Q4, where we had a massive push with large deals. And then we don't see any change in that landscape whatsoever.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And one of the factors that impacts growth rate was you refreshed all of your product line a little over a year ago. So last year, we enjoyed quite a bit of acceleration in growth rate. You're coming off of tough comps. Are you seeing any impact from just
componenttext: And one of the factors that impacts growth rate was you refreshed all of your product line a little over a year ago. So last year, we enjoyed quite a bit of acceleration in growth rate. You're coming off of tough comps. Are you seeing any impact from just the pent-up demand maybe that was created from the product cycle and just things slowing down after people went ahead and did the refreshes. Any thoughts on that as a driver?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we thought about that. And if you look at the drivers, and it's probably worth through them again, just to summarize. But obviously, product refresh, we've talked about there. It was a low-hanging fruit at the beginning. It's not quite there at the mo
componenttext: No, we thought about that. And if you look at the drivers, and it's probably worth through them again, just to summarize. But obviously, product refresh, we've talked about there. It was a low-hanging fruit at the beginning. It's not quite there at the moment, probably. Do we still have a very large installed base of products that we can refresh? Absolutely. So I think of that area. Obviously, the 1200 with its SSL capability, I think is clearly -- as one point our product, but with its SSL capability, that's a pretty good opportunity to refresh as well. But the big drivers are security, with the firewall that we talked about, ASM, I think WAP solution, our DDoS on-prem and off-premise. And then as a service provider, we feel very good with the drivers there from NFV, from a security perspective, PCP optimization. We still feel good about ACE. I mentioned about what we're going to do there. And the SDN partnerships and in general, the cloud movement I think is a growth possibility for us. So product refresh, probably to some degree, but we still think there's a big opportunity there.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, last question. Given the growth in pipeline, partly the new creation as well as deals slipping, with your guidance, that product growth rate continued to decelerate to somewhere near high single digits when you look at your guidance. How do you get
componenttext: Okay, last question. Given the growth in pipeline, partly the new creation as well as deals slipping, with your guidance, that product growth rate continued to decelerate to somewhere near high single digits when you look at your guidance. How do you get this back up? And why isn't the guidance for the March quarter better just given the buildup of the million-dollar plus projects?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, historically, March-quarter, you need to be careful with that because it's always the beginning of a financial year for a lot of companies. We are assuming, I hope relatively conservative close rates in the factor pipeline. And we'll see where tha
componenttext: I mean, historically, March-quarter, you need to be careful with that because it's always the beginning of a financial year for a lot of companies. We are assuming, I hope relatively conservative close rates in the factor pipeline. And we'll see where that takes us.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question Subu Subrahmanyan, group.
componenttext: Next question Subu Subrahmanyan, group.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First on the service provider side, if you could talk about, given the CapEx backdrop, you certainly have some wins and share gain opportunities. So how do you think about the service provider vertical for this year? Do you expect it to gro
componenttext: Two questions. First on the service provider side, if you could talk about, given the CapEx backdrop, you certainly have some wins and share gain opportunities. So how do you think about the service provider vertical for this year? Do you expect it to grow as a percentage of revenues in fiscal '14? And then on the virtualization side, I certainly, hear you, John, that the deals are large. But if you do a comparison with the architectural changes, if you had sold all hardware instances, as you might have a few years ago versus a mix of hardware and software, what that is doing to the overall dollar value of the deals and also the profitability of the deals? That would be helpful.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me -- this is Manny. Let me answer the service provider. On the service provider, we have 4 major drivers that I think we talked a little bit about. They were definitely in John's prepared comments, which is consolidation across the board from a se
componenttext: So let me -- this is Manny. Let me answer the service provider. On the service provider, we have 4 major drivers that I think we talked a little bit about. They were definitely in John's prepared comments, which is consolidation across the board from a service provider point of view, and that's consolidation of services, predominantly traffic steering services, carrier grid map services and some other services in there that we're consolidated inside that environment. That reduces CapEx really for many of the operators there, because they're going from multi vendors to a single vendor. Second major driver we have is security, which is also something we can overlay on that same footprint, again from a consolidation point of view. But we call it out as a separate driver because it's just the impact from the size associated with that, but there is NFV and the NFV footprints that we're seeing out there, which are still early proof of concepts to some degree and we are in various proof of concepts across the world. We're starting to see some of those pan out, and that's what happened this past quarter and why we had a big bump also on our software sales. And the last is the LTE or the mobility movement going to 4G networks, which we've been seeding in the customer environment for the last 2 years. And we're starting to see there also from a driver perspective that these networks get deployed, get accepted. Usage volume goes up, new devices are being enabled, meaning additional mobile handsets, but also new devices from the perspective of the Internet of Things that we're going to see additional software license there. So those are predominantly the 4 major drivers and those are usually either tackling the CapEx volume from a consolidation point of view or the monetization line from something along the perspective of LTE and being able to bring on new services to the market.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the virtualization side of things, which I think is very similar to the answer I gave to a similar question, which was basically -- first of all, these are still smaller numbers. I mean this is still a relatively small market versus overall ADC mar
componenttext: And on the virtualization side of things, which I think is very similar to the answer I gave to a similar question, which was basically -- first of all, these are still smaller numbers. I mean this is still a relatively small market versus overall ADC market. But the deals that we're seeing are pretty large in nature, and yes, we need to market exactly to see the [indiscernible] if it's all hardware versus all software. I'm not sure we're going to see much difference, quite frankly. So I don't think that's a -- if you're looking for, is that the factor and what happened in terms of bringing us to the low-end of the range, we don't think so.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to add one more comment, Manny again, on the software side that we see, is we see an expansion of the application needs in the market segment. What I mean by that is historically, a handful of applications in the typical enterprise or service pro
componenttext: And just to add one more comment, Manny again, on the software side that we see, is we see an expansion of the application needs in the market segment. What I mean by that is historically, a handful of applications in the typical enterprise or service provider got the ADC services because it was harder to deploy and much more complex. As we move toward much more software-based architectures, what you see is a broader set of applications getting these services because it's easier to deploy those services in the environment. So it's actually, to a large degree, an expansion in the market.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Next question from Brent Bracelin, Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Two quick follow-ups, if I could. On the million-dollar deals, if you look at across the broader enterprise, we've actually seen a trend towards, and you did as well, up until this quarter an increasing number of larger deals that closed. Do you think what you saw in December was company-specific? or do you think there were other factors here at play? And I have one follow-up.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes, that's a really hard one. We don't know the answer to that, Brent. We just don't know the answer. I think as more companies announce, then there may be some more news here. But I certainly wouldn't call out, and that's why we're not calling out,
componenttext: Oh, yes, that's a really hard one. We don't know the answer to that, Brent. We just don't know the answer. I think as more companies announce, then there may be some more news here. But I certainly wouldn't call out, and that's why we're not calling out, as Michael asked us, quite frankly. I mean, the other side of the coin is that, that create rate that we had is probably the biggest create rate we've seen, if not the biggest, and certainly one of the biggest. And I'm talking about large deals. So yes, time will tell in terms of whether it's a bigger issue or not.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then the follow-up question is back to software. And as we've kind of compare and contrast the software growth rate versus your reported product growth rate, it was 44% software growth rate this quarter versus 10% product growth. If
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then the follow-up question is back to software. And as we've kind of compare and contrast the software growth rate versus your reported product growth rate, it was 44% software growth rate this quarter versus 10% product growth. If I look at your Analyst Day, you talked about I think 41% security software growth rate versus 17% product growth rate, so there's a widening gap there between kind of the growth in software versus product appliance overall. Why shouldn't we expect slightly more tempered growth going forward with a mix shift to software, given the trends over the last couple of quarters? And frankly now, given some of the announcements around new products, where you're going to be pricing those products on a subscription basis?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I mean I think if you take a medium to longer-term view, that's correct. That is absolutely correct. You're going to see us selling more and more software. We've done that now. We pushed the sales force to do that. It's our competitive edge. It
componenttext: Yes, well, I mean I think if you take a medium to longer-term view, that's correct. That is absolutely correct. You're going to see us selling more and more software. We've done that now. We pushed the sales force to do that. It's our competitive edge. It's obviously very, very profitable. We think we're in great shape in terms of our BIG-IQ orchestration for managing software across clouds and clouds across data centers, et cetera. So you will see that. I don't think it's going to be a complete revolutionary process. I think it's going to be evolutionary. If you look at the -- it's interesting, if you look at the Gi firewall opportunities, the software content in that, of course is very significant, but so is actually the hardware content because it needs to cope with a significant amount of traffic either on the DDoS side of things or just in pure mobile traffic firewall protection, so I think the trends are going to be there. But to take 1 quarter from Q4 to Q1 and say that's a trend, I think, would be very dangerous. We don't believe that.
