headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to F5 Networks Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, please disconnect at this time. And now, I will
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to F5 Networks Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, please disconnect at this time. And now, I will turn the call over to Mr. John Eldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katie. Welcome to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2015. Manny Rivelo, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of the executive team, including Jo
componenttext:
Thank you, Katie. Welcome to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2015. Manny Rivelo, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of the executive team, including John DiLullo, our new EVP of Worldwide Sales, are also on hand to answer questions following their prepared remarks.
If you have any follow-up questions after the call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6571. A copy of today's press release is available on our website at f5.com. In addition, you can access an archived version of today's live webcast from the Events Calendar page of our website through January 20. From 4:30 p.m. today until 5 p.m., Pacific Time on October 29, you can also listen to a telephone replay at (800) 876-6785 or (402) 220-5331.
During today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements that include words such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve uncertainties and risks that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements. Factors that may affect our results are summarized in our quarterly release and described in detail on our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented on this call.
Before we begin the call, I want to remind you that we are holding our 2015 Analyst Investor meeting at New York Hilton Midtown on Thursday, November 12. If you plan to attend the meeting, you can register online from the link on our IR Events Calendar page entry for November 12.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Andy Reinland.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. As I normally do on our Q4 call, I will first discuss our results for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year ended September 30; then I will provide guidance for the current quarter; and finally, outline our general planning assumptions a
componenttext:
Thank you, John. As I normally do on our Q4 call, I will first discuss our results for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year ended September 30; then I will provide guidance for the current quarter; and finally, outline our general planning assumptions and expectations for fiscal year 2016.
We ended fiscal 2015 with an annual revenue run rate of $2 billion and record earnings per share. Revenue of $501.3 million was up 8% compared to Q4 '14 and within our guided range of $500 million to $510 million. GAAP EPS was $1.36 per share, above our guidance of $1.26 to $1.29 per share. Non-GAAP EPS of $1.84 also exceeded our guidance of $1.72 to $1.75 per share.
Q4 product revenue of $257.7 million, up 4% from Q3 and 1% from the fourth quarter of last year represented 51% of revenue. Service revenue of $243.6 million increased 4% sequentially, 16% year-over-year and accounted for 49% of revenue.
On a regional basis, the Americas grew 7% year-over-year and represented 58% of revenue, with the strongest growth in the U.S., while a difficult macro environment slowed sales in Latin America and Canada. EMEA grew 11% year-over-year and accounted for 23% of overall revenue. APAC, which accounted for 15% of revenue, increased 12% year-over-year. And Japan, at 4% of revenue, was down 6% from a year ago. Enterprise customers represented 65% of total Q4 sales. Service providers accounted for 17%, and government sales were 17%, including 9% from U.S. Federal.
During the quarter, we have 3 greater-than-10% distributors. Westcon, which accounted for 17.2% of total revenue; Ingram Micro, which accounted for 15.6%; and Avnet at 14.3%. 
Continuing down the income statement. GAAP gross margin in Q4 was 83.1%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 84.4%. GAAP operating expenses of $269 million were at the low end of our $267 million to $276 million guided range. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $230.4 million.
Our GAAP operating margin in Q4 was 29.4%, and non-GAAP operating margin was 38.4%. Our GAAP effective tax rate for the quarter was 35.1%, and our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 32.8%.
Turning to the balance sheet. In Q4, we generated $183 million in cash flow from operations, which contributed to cash and investments totaling $1.17 billion at year-end. DSO was 50 days. Inventory at the end of the quarter was $33.7 million. Deferred revenue increased 23% year-over-year to $783.3 million.
In Q4, we repurchased approximately 1.18 million shares of our common stock at an average price of $126.99 per share for a total of $150 million. Approximately $474 million remains authorized under the current share repurchase program.
During the quarter, we closed our test facility in Tomsk, Russia, eliminating approximately 65 positions. These will be reinvested in other locations over the first half of fiscal 2016. Across the rest of the company, we added a very strong 135 net employees.
For the full year, revenue for fiscal 2015 was $1.92 billion, up 11% from fiscal 2014. Product revenue of $991.5 million was up 6% from the prior year and accounted for 52% of total revenue. Service revenue of $928.3 million grew 17% during the year and represented 48% of the total. GAAP net income for fiscal 2015 was $365 million or $5.03 per share, and non-GAAP net income was $480.3 million or $6.62 per share. And for all of fiscal 2015, cash flow from operations totaled $685 million.
Moving onto our guidance for Q1 and our fiscal year '16 outlook. As we entered fiscal 2016, the growth of IP traffic and connected devices, the proliferation of applications and virtualized data centers in the cloud and the increase in the number and types and security threats all challenged the fast, secure and reliable delivery of applications to increasingly mobile users. Over the past several years, the pace of innovation at F5 has accelerated to deliver products and services that enable customers to meet these challenges by leveraging the cloud, SDN, NFV and other emerging technologies that are reshaping the industry. As a result of these efforts, our absolute focus on the application, continuing technology leadership of our full proxy architecture and our disciplined business model, I am confident that we will see a return to year-over-year product revenue growth and continued solid EPS growth in the coming year.
During the past 2 quarters, F5 has had several key management transitions, consisting of both new leadership and realignment of certain internal responsibilities. These moves have already resulted in positive changes to our organizational structure, product road map and sales motions that are designed to reaccelerate and drive product revenue growth in the current fiscal year and beyond.
As we enter our fiscal 2016, we are anticipating seasonal softness we typically experience in Q1. We also continue to be cautious due to budget uncertainty driven by foreign currency fluctuations and lingering macro issues. With this in mind, for the first quarter of fiscal 2016, we are targeting revenue in the range of $480 million to $490 million. We expect GAAP gross margins at or around 82.5%, including approximately $4 million of stock-based compensation expense and $2.7 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. Non-GAAP gross margins are anticipated at or around 84%.
We estimate GAAP operating expense of $268 million to $277 million, including approximately $35 million of stock-based compensation expense and $0.7 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. We anticipate a GAAP effective tax rate of 37.5% for the quarter and a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 34.5%.
Our Q1 GAAP earnings target is $1.13 to $1.16 per share. Our non-GAAP earnings target is $1.58 to $1.61 per share. We believe we will generate cash flow from operations in excess of $195 million, and we plan to increase our headcount by up to 100 employees during the quarter.
Looking out to the fiscal year ahead, our general planning assumptions and expectations for the year are as follows: From the base of Q1, we anticipate sequential revenue growth throughout the year, with a strong second half of the fiscal year. We anticipate that non-GAAP gross margins will remain in the 83.5% to 84.5% range. We expect non-GAAP operating margins in the mid-30s range for the first half of the year and increasing through the second half. Stock-based compensation is anticipated to be in the range of $160 million to $170 million for the year. Capital expenditures are expected to range from $15 million to $20 million per quarter for ongoing infrastructure investments and facilities expansions. And finally, assuming the R&D tax credit is not extended during fiscal 2016, we expect our effective tax rate to average approximately 37% to 38% on a GAAP basis and 34% to 35% on a non-GAAP basis for the year.
As John mentioned, our Analyst Investor meeting will be November 12 in New York. We hope you can join us as our executive team presents the company strategy and go-to-market plans for F5.
With that, I will turn the call over to Manny Rivelo.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andy. I would like to thank everybody for joining F5's 2015 Q4 Earnings Conference Call.Overall, I'm pleased with the performance this fiscal year. We closed FY '15 with a number of key milestones: Revenues of $1.9 billion with solid financia
componenttext:
Thank you, Andy. I would like to thank everybody for joining F5's 2015 Q4 Earnings Conference Call.
Overall, I'm pleased with the performance this fiscal year. We closed FY '15 with a number of key milestones: Revenues of $1.9 billion with solid financial performance and record non-GAAP earnings per share of $6.62.
We continue to outpace our competition with our hybrid application services strategy. Year-to-date, we've increased our virtual ADC market share by 13 points and the overall ADC market share by 3 points for a total share of 49% as of the latest industry reports. And for the ninth year in a row, we remained the leader in the 2015 Gartner Magic Quadrant for ADC. We continue to diversify with more than 1/3 of our revenue coming from software sales, driven largely by the demand for security and the uptake of our "Good, Better, Best" licensing and continued strength with our virtualization sales. Approximately 41% of total product sales in FY '15 included one or more security products. This represents a 22% year-over-year growth, driven in large part by our wins in government, financial service and service providers.
Demonstrating the power of our programmable platform, we exceeded 223,000 members in our DevCentral user community, representing a 22% year-over-year growth. And lastly, we are approaching 4,200 global employees. 
It took us 15 years to reach $1 billion in sales. A mere 4 years later, in Q4, we exited the year at $501 million in sales, putting us at a $2 billion run rate. As you heard from Andy, we had a solid fourth quarter, meeting our revenue guidance and achieving record profitability. From a regional perspective, U.S. enterprise had a good quarter. However, overall Americas bookings were behind our internal expectations. We attribute this to the market volatility and the currency fluctuations in Latin America and Canada and some delays in project-driven service provider transactions.
In EMEA, we saw bookings in line with our internal expectations. Bookings at our Asia-Pac region exceeded our targets and showed strong year-over-year growth, while Japan sales was down year-over-year but in line with our internal projections.
In the core of our ADC market, we enjoyed a good quarter. In August, we released the traffic management operating system, TMOS version 12.0. This is a meaningful major release that allows customers to more easily transition workloads to the cloud and incorporate technologies like HTTP 2.0, while maintaining the same visibility, security and control of traditional infrastructures. 
Our programmable extensible architecture and growing ecosystem of technology partners make our application services an ideal fit for emerging IT trends such as software-defined networking, network function virtualization and the cloud. We see many emerging opportunities from new projects enabled by our hybrid application services. Our recent F5 global survey of over 3,000 customers showed that 81% plan to run the applications in a hybrid, a private-public cloud environment. We see this trend reflected in our virtualization sales, which were up 57% for the full fiscal year.
In Q4, we launched the F5 Ready program to verify F5 virtualization compatibility with a growing of public cloud service providers. This includes Amazon Web Services, Blue Lock, British Telecom, Cisco Intercloud, Datacom, Dimension Data, Microsoft Azure, Rackspace, Single Hop, Sky Tap and VMware and VCloud Air. The F5 Ready program makes it possible for our customers to run their applications and application services in the cloud environment of their choice. 
We still continue to see opportunities in Cisco ACE replacement. We also see opportunities in selling additional F5 modules to new ACE replacement customers. For example, in Q4, we won a competitive million dollar ACE replacement order at a Fortune 100 company, chiefly due to our strength in SDN. 
Hybrid deployments are driving security requirements for our customers' cloud adoption. Nearly half, 48% of the customers we surveyed cited consistent policy and audibility of on -- with on-premise as an important security factor for their cloud adoption. We see this trend reflected in our wins. 
In Q4, a global consulting firm replaced Juniper with F5's remote access in single sign-on solutions across their cloud and on-premise applications.
Because of our strategic point of control at many customers' networks, more and more of our accounts are implementing F5 hybrid security services to combat the increasing volume and sophistication of high-profile cybersecurity breaches. In April, we launched a new Silverline Web application firewall, a WAF as a service, and although it's early days, we are seeing solid interest from our customers and sale organization for our cloud-based offerings, tripling our Silverline customer base this past year.
This past quarter, based on our growing Silverline and Versafe customer demand, we opened a second security operations center in Poland. The team of highly specialized F5 security researchers and analysts in Warsaw will complement our existing facility here in Seattle. Monitoring and investigating global multilayer attacks, the center will maintain up-to-date information on the latest malware, 0-day and phishing attacks.
In the service provider industry, a recent survey shows that on a daily basis, an average Tier 1 operator experiences roughly 10 to 15 DDoS attacks and 2,000 application attacks which can result in leaked customer data, intercepted or blocked calls, roaming fraud as well as deterioration of network and service performance. These trends have increasingly driven growth of our security offerings within our service provider business.
In particular, we are enjoying rapid expansion in our U.S. carrier segment where our Gi LAN and anti-DDoS service capabilities as well as our firewall and application protection capabilities are helping us to secure competitive multimillion dollar repeat wins. 
As the demand for high bandwidth, low latency networks only increases, our NFE, TCP optimization and advanced traffic steering solutions are helping our service provider customers significantly increase their efficiency and ensure their peak network performance. We signed several multimillion dollar agreements in the past quarter that further evidenced our carrier freight capabilities.
In addition, we have increased our NFE partner ecosystem. In Q4, we announced a partnership with HP, Nuage and Telstra to demonstrate a proof of concept for a multi-vendor open NFE solution. Certified by the European Telecommunications Standard Institute, ETSI, this proof of concept demonstrates to service providers how NFE can reduce TCO while increasing service agility and network elasticity.
Our service business continues to produce with 17% year-over-year revenue growth for the full fiscal year. New and renewed service maintenance contracts grow with deferred revenue growth to 783 million this quarter, up 23% year-over-year, providing a solid foundation for continued services to grow. 
Our services strength also underscores how our world-class, high-valued customer support drives product revenue growth. For example, in Q4, a U.S. bank leveraged our professional services for a technology refresh project. We're seen to expand their use of our application models to include an application security module and a DNS solution in a multimillion dollar deal. 
Our base of SDN, cloud, application provider, service provider and converge system technology partners is as strong as ever. I want to expand on one particular security partnership that we formed in Q4. We added FireEye, an industry leader in network security, to help our customers defend against today's advanced cyber attacks. F5 and FireEye will offer customer network segmentation and policy management, protocol conformance, DDoS mitigation, SSL inspection, advanced threat protection, intrusion prevention, threat intelligence, forensics and analytics. Although we're just launching our partnership, our joint security offerings have already resulted in a multimillion sale to a U.S. health product company. 
Let me spend a moment now on our leadership team. I'm pleased to report that the sales team transition under John DiLullo has been smooth. John's global sales and channel experience and deep industry relationships combined with new FY '16 initiatives will enable F5 sales evolution and drive accelerated product revenue growth.
Secondly, I have asked Julian Eames to expand his responsibilities and centralize our support functions in global services, manufacturing, IT, program management and facilities under his leadership as our new Chief Operations Officer.
To reiterate my earlier comments, I believe our growth drivers for fiscal 2016 will be driven by our big IP releases, security-specific offers, sales and channel productivity gains, cloud and Silverline sales acceleration and a favorable product refresh cycle anticipated in the back end of this fiscal year.
As far as the Q1 outlook is concerned, Andy indicated that we expect revenues in the $480 million to $490 million range. We are taking measured view of our Q1 business in light of several macro economic uncertainties and the historical impact of seasonality on our Q1 order [indiscernible].
As Andy also mentioned, we expect to deliver sequential quarter-over-quarter growth through the rest of fiscal 2016, and we will continue to invest in activities that further extend our leadership position or help us to capture incremental opportunities as they arise.
As the market evolves, so too does F5. By having net application as our focus, we have been able to grow and flex the new customer demands.
Kicking off our new fiscal year this month, we have a clear sense of purpose, expanding our core offerings in ADC to the cloud, extending into strategic markets of security, F5 as a service via Silverline and the service provider and driving a world-class customer experience from our global services organization. As I stated at the beginning of my commentary, I'm excited about the opportunities presented by our hybrid application services strategy. Our customers are moving beyond hybrid architectures and our focus on software application service is clearly positioning us to capture new workloads and new markets.
The leadership team and I are looking forward to sharing these plans with you at our Annual Investor Meeting on November 12 in New York City.
In closing, I would like to thank the entire F5 team, our partners and customers for their support last quarter. We look forward to a great Q1. I will now open the call up for Q&A.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is from the line of Jim Suva of Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is from the line of Jim Suva of Citi.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question is on the statement that you put out in the press release about the planned production rollout of the new sales initiatives, that the combined effect would be gradual and weighted toward the back half of the year. Can you help us understand a
componenttext: My question is on the statement that you put out in the press release about the planned production rollout of the new sales initiatives, that the combined effect would be gradual and weighted toward the back half of the year. Can you help us understand a little bit about, does that mean the rollout of the new products are in the back of the year? Or they're rolling out and then companies have an opportunity to test them kind of in the first half of the year and then the actual financial benefit comes in the second half of the year?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, there is -- this is Manny. There might be 2 questions in there. From a product perspective, we have approximately 2 major software releases in here. We just had 1 that came out in August. We see that being material throughout the course of t
componenttext: Yes, I think, there is -- this is Manny. There might be 2 questions in there. From a product perspective, we have approximately 2 major software releases in here. We just had 1 that came out in August. We see that being material throughout the course of this year. We'll have a second software release that comes out here in the -- near the second half of the year. We also -- I referred to product refresh, which is basically our hardware product refresh. We made a commitment to refresh that approximately every 3 years, and we're at that turning point. We see that happening toward the later part of this year also, more into Q3, later Q4 timeframe. And then, from a sales initiatives perspective, I guess, what I'll comment on, and John, if you want to add to that afterwards, is really, we -- as we continue to expand into the new markets, whether it be security or service provider, we're continuing to specialize our sales organizations in those areas. So it's some of the initiatives of how we continue to specialize our sales teams as well as our channel organization to better capture the emerging opportunities there.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Pierre Ferragu of Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Pierre Ferragu of Bernstein.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, there is really like 2 software concerns, I would say, in terms of your revenue momentum. One is the hyper growth of cloud helping you. And the second one is the idea that you might have benefited a lot from like a weak competitive environment an
componenttext: I think, there is really like 2 software concerns, I would say, in terms of your revenue momentum. One is the hyper growth of cloud helping you. And the second one is the idea that you might have benefited a lot from like a weak competitive environment and that you've been growing faster than the market and that maybe now, it's going to be better for you to grow some. So my 2 questions would be on the cloud, when you see your clients moving to the cloud, is that a net benefit to you and are you very clearly seeing that? Although that means that people -- your clients are buying less on premises and there is a large amount of cannibalization. And then, the second one on the competitive landscape, you mentioned that you are gaining still a good traction on the [indiscernible] of Cisco. Do you see anything changing that would justify a slower growth going forward in your competitive landscape, be it on the net scale side of things? Are they getting more aggressive? Or do you see like the end of the opportunity to take share from Cisco domain?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start. This is Manny. I'll start with the cloud, and turn it over to Karl and then maybe we'll come back and talk about the competitive environment. So on the cloud, the key point is when we talk to our customers, they're looking for hybrid archite
componenttext: Let me start. This is Manny. I'll start with the cloud, and turn it over to Karl and then maybe we'll come back and talk about the competitive environment. So on the cloud, the key point is when we talk to our customers, they're looking for hybrid architectures. And what that basically means is solutions that both enables on-prem and off-prem, and when they go off-prem, to also be multi-cloud, not single cloud provider. So we see that as a massive opportunity for us to be able to create a solution set across the environment that we allow application-to-application service portability out there. So that's the big -- a major driver for us. Obviously, above and beyond that, we're also making sure that our solution is in all of the major cloud instances so we're easy to find from a customer perspective. I don't know if you want to add anything, Karl?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just add to that real quick. There's 1 good data point here, by the way, it's Karl speaking, is that our software versions of our products are the fastest-growing part of our business right now, and that's what we're using to support effectively
componenttext: Yes, I'll just add to that real quick. There's 1 good data point here, by the way, it's Karl speaking, is that our software versions of our products are the fastest-growing part of our business right now, and that's what we're using to support effectively this hybrid cloud focus. And there's a number of areas that we address holistically with this. One of the big key ones, like Manny mentioned, is the ability to have this portability between clouds and the data center and consistent policies. And with consistent policies, what they mean by that is both security as well as access policies. And so as part of our latest release and kind of core to our products is the ability to provide this federated access so that we can front end both public, private as well as kind of traditional data centers, including SaaS-based applications as well. The other components are things like customers want to be able to have capacity augmentation with the cloud. To be able to do that, of course, you need to have kind of these consistent policies, and we provide that. Security services is a key area. You need to have audibility and the ability to have that consistency between what they're doing on-prem and off-prem and provide consistent services and all that. And so there's a number of things that we do there. If you look at our latest release, in fact, we added a lot of other key features that made us operate much better in some of the biggest public clouds like Azure and AWS. And so we've been there for quite a while. So there's definitely an opportunity there, and we're innovating and quickly working towards that because that's where our customers are taking us.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to answer the second question on the competitive environment. If you look at the history of F5, we've had a good -- a lot of competitors over the years. And we assume we're going to continue to see competitors popping up over the years. So althou
componenttext: And just to answer the second question on the competitive environment. If you look at the history of F5, we've had a good -- a lot of competitors over the years. And we assume we're going to continue to see competitors popping up over the years. So although we've been winning market share this past year at a significant rate and we've been winning our fair share of Cisco ACE accounts, we think there's still room for improvement there. So we'll be working hard. We have programs in place. We have technology refresh cycles. We have integration with our partner ecosystem on cloud, SDN is an example to ensure that we continue to gain market share in the market. But we do have a healthy market share right now, approximately 50% of the market, and we've been growing aggressively, as I stated, our virtual instances, and as Karl pointed out, one of our fastest-growing parts of our business.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Ryan Hutchinson with Guggenheim.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Ryan Hutchinson with Guggenheim.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: They sort of just asked the question that I had around cloud service provider, but just to follow up on that, can you just help us understand the dynamics as it relates to the market share, specifically with AWS, and whether or not you think you're a shar
componenttext: They sort of just asked the question that I had around cloud service provider, but just to follow up on that, can you just help us understand the dynamics as it relates to the market share, specifically with AWS, and whether or not you think you're a shared owner at the expense of some of those opportunities? And how we should think about that moving forward? And then, as a clarification, just around guidance. I have a question on whether or not the sequential growth will be for both product and service? Or any color around that and planning assumptions would be helpful as we think about the full year.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Why don't we start with the guidance question, Andy.
componenttext: Why don't we start with the guidance question, Andy.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we -- Ryan, you know us, we don't guide product and services separately, but our #1 goal is to drive product revenue and that's our focus. And we know that pulls the services along with it. So our initiatives and focus are all pointed towards prod
componenttext: Yes. So we -- Ryan, you know us, we don't guide product and services separately, but our #1 goal is to drive product revenue and that's our focus. And we know that pulls the services along with it. So our initiatives and focus are all pointed towards product revenue growth.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And this is Karl again. You asked a question about AWS and do we see that as a net opportunity, and that's absolutely the case. We've been running there for quite some time. We're enhancing our capabilities and we're seeing substantial growth in our busin
componenttext: And this is Karl again. You asked a question about AWS and do we see that as a net opportunity, and that's absolutely the case. We've been running there for quite some time. We're enhancing our capabilities and we're seeing substantial growth in our business there. So -- and -- so we see that as a growth opportunity and an expansion opportunity. Like I said earlier, the #1 thing customers talk about who are moving to public cloud is this notion of being able -- not be locked in, that they have portability and they can move that and we help enable that with our application services.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just, Ryan, it's Manny, just to add something. We're seeing lots of use cases that are multi-cloud environments, which are customers that not only have their own data centers that have workloads that are running potentially an AWS, but also in Rackspa
componenttext: And just, Ryan, it's Manny, just to add something. We're seeing lots of use cases that are multi-cloud environments, which are customers that not only have their own data centers that have workloads that are running potentially an AWS, but also in Rackspace or Azure and they're using all that infrastructure, if you will, to run their application environments. And giving choice to their customers usually aligns the business to where they want to deploy those services. Part of the reason why we wanted to make it easy for customers to understand that we're in those environments and that's why we launched the F5 Ready program because those are cloud providers that we certified our solutions and are making it easy to deploy our application services in.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Brian White with Drexel.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Brian White with Drexel.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could give us a little more color what's happening in America? It sounds like the U.S. is still very strong, but outside the U.S. is weakness. Are you seeing weakness in other geographies as we go forward? Maybe just color on the macro env
componenttext: I wonder if you could give us a little more color what's happening in America? It sounds like the U.S. is still very strong, but outside the U.S. is weakness. Are you seeing weakness in other geographies as we go forward? Maybe just color on the macro environment side.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as Manny mentioned and I mentioned as well, Latin America is an area with foreign currency fluctuations. They're really affecting budgets and people's comfort level with committing funds. Canada, we saw weakness there. There are pockets in Europe, in
componenttext: Yes, as Manny mentioned and I mentioned as well, Latin America is an area with foreign currency fluctuations. They're really affecting budgets and people's comfort level with committing funds. Canada, we saw weakness there. There are pockets in Europe, in Eastern Europe, Southern that I think, when I commented on lingering issues, those areas haven't improved and we've seen that for a long period of time. So the growth rates there just aren't as strong as we'd like them to be, and some areas of APAC similar to that.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And when we think of the partnership here with FireEye, is this going to be material in fiscal '16? Or is this more of a fiscal '17 story?
componenttext: And when we think of the partnership here with FireEye, is this going to be material in fiscal '16? Or is this more of a fiscal '17 story?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: It should be a fiscal '16 and going on hopefully to '17. We just warmed it. It's hot off the press here, if you will. It's 30 days or so ago. We're seeing great traction in the field from a go-to-market momentum, our sales organization. We just had our Am
componenttext: It should be a fiscal '16 and going on hopefully to '17. We just warmed it. It's hot off the press here, if you will. It's 30 days or so ago. We're seeing great traction in the field from a go-to-market momentum, our sales organization. We just had our Americas QBR earlier this week and they came out up repeatedly from the sales leadership of good traction in the field and good engagement. So we anticipate it'll be material in FY '16 and then carryforward from a solution set perspective. We have very complementary set of technologies of the 2 companies with very little overlap. And as a result of that, that creates a very fluid and natural sales motion since our sales organizations can provide a better solution together, and there's no real conflict on where the revenue is going to come from.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Alex Kurtz of Sterne Agee.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Alex Kurtz of Sterne Agee.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Andy, on the deferred revenue, it looked like it was pretty strong in the quarter, just any color there on what drove that year-over-year sequentially? Is there any kind of change in how the software is charged? Or is there some kind of mix issue that's s
componenttext: Andy, on the deferred revenue, it looked like it was pretty strong in the quarter, just any color there on what drove that year-over-year sequentially? Is there any kind of change in how the software is charged? Or is there some kind of mix issue that's sort of helping the deferred line and how we should think about that going forward?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's no real change in terms of sales motion or how we go about giving the renewals there that really drive the deferred revenue. We are being much more aggressive going after multiyear deals and so we've seen our long-term element of the deferred
componenttext: Yes. There's no real change in terms of sales motion or how we go about giving the renewals there that really drive the deferred revenue. We are being much more aggressive going after multiyear deals and so we've seen our long-term element of the deferred revenue grow. I think, it was approaching 27%.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Or 23%, sorry. But yes -- and a lot of the customers want to lock in their pricing for multiple years, so we're taking advantage of that and pushing for those agreements. And we're also pushing very hard for premium plus type services, and we have been ha
componenttext: Or 23%, sorry. But yes -- and a lot of the customers want to lock in their pricing for multiple years, so we're taking advantage of that and pushing for those agreements. And we're also pushing very hard for premium plus type services, and we have been having success with that. And we see that as key strategically for us because we know if they buy premium plus services, the relationship is just that much stronger and it does lead to more hardware sales, so we put a big focus on that.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Erik Suppiger of JMP.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Erik Suppiger of JMP.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First off, I'm just curious, you talked about SDN. Are you seeing more opportunity to work with Cisco's ACI, or more opportunity with VMware's NSX solutions at this point?
componenttext: First off, I'm just curious, you talked about SDN. Are you seeing more opportunity to work with Cisco's ACI, or more opportunity with VMware's NSX solutions at this point?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Manny, and I'll turn it over to Karl here also. But we're seeing both, we're seeing good momentum with both, there's lots of proof of concept. It's still fairly early from a deployment perspective from what we can tell. We do have deployment
componenttext: Yes, this is Manny, and I'll turn it over to Karl here also. But we're seeing both, we're seeing good momentum with both, there's lots of proof of concept. It's still fairly early from a deployment perspective from what we can tell. We do have deployment instances out there that we're working actively. But it depends on who the buyer is, is what we're seeing from an SDN perspective. It's a traditional networking buyer. We're seeing that fall sometimes a little more favorably in the Cisco camp. If it's an application buyer looking for segmentation, it's all squarely in the VMware camp. So we're seeing interest in both. And in some accounts, we're seeing interest in actually both also, meaning that a certain customer may have both Cisco's solution and an NSX solution from VMware. Anything you want to add, Karl?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm just going to add. OpenStack is actually where we're seeing a lot of interest and momentum, especially with service providers when looking at [indiscernible] actually as well as enterprises. And so that's kind of, I think, the third leg of that S
componenttext: Yes, I'm just going to add. OpenStack is actually where we're seeing a lot of interest and momentum, especially with service providers when looking at [indiscernible] actually as well as enterprises. And so that's kind of, I think, the third leg of that SDN tool is that we're making really good progress with both VMware and Cisco, but OpenStack is definitely top of mind for many, many companies or service providers out there right now. And obviously, we're supporting that very aggressively as well.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you see more business with OpenStack than either Cisco or NSX?
componenttext: Do you see more business with OpenStack than either Cisco or NSX?

componenttextpreview: It's all pretty early days right now. I mean, a lot of this is still proof of concept. So it's fairly nascent with the customers, but it's hard to say at this point.
componenttext: It's all pretty early days right now. I mean, a lot of this is still proof of concept. So it's fairly nascent with the customers, but it's hard to say at this point.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, second question, Office 365 is performing relatively well these days. Do you have much of an opportunity to play on that market as well?
componenttext: Okay. And then, second question, Office 365 is performing relatively well these days. Do you have much of an opportunity to play on that market as well?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I mean, this is Karl again. If you look at things like being able to provide federated access to the applications, that's one of our major use cases for Office 365. In fact, we are an Office 365 shop here at F5. So again, Microsoft's been a ma
componenttext: Absolutely. I mean, this is Karl again. If you look at things like being able to provide federated access to the applications, that's one of our major use cases for Office 365. In fact, we are an Office 365 shop here at F5. So again, Microsoft's been a major partner of ours for many, many years as part of that. So yes, we have major use cases around it, also other types of security as well as optimization for them, and we're obviously also a part of the Azure cloud.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And we've actually integrated our solution and our programmability via iApps for Office 365, to Karl's point, to make it easy for customers to deploy single sign-on of those services. So it's a plain opportunity for our customer base and for us.
componenttext: Yes. And we've actually integrated our solution and our programmability via iApps for Office 365, to Karl's point, to make it easy for customers to deploy single sign-on of those services. So it's a plain opportunity for our customer base and for us.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Tal Liani of Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Tal Liani of Bank of America.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have some kind of a high-level question, which is your growth rate, if I -- sorry, government growth was very strong this quarter, 39-and-change percent. And if I remove the government segment from your revenues and I recalculate the growth for the enti
componenttext: I have some kind of a high-level question, which is your growth rate, if I -- sorry, government growth was very strong this quarter, 39-and-change percent. And if I remove the government segment from your revenues and I recalculate the growth for the entire company, product and services included, your growth rate peaked at 20% in Q2 and Q3 of last year, and since then, every quarter, it's coming down. It's gone down to 5.4% only this quarter and 6.4% the previous quarter. So what is causing this massive deceleration in the growth rate in an environment that should have been good for you given the competitive landscape and your product portfolio and et cetera? So why don't we see higher growth rates or at least flat growth rate instead of such a deceleration? And that's, again, x government.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tal Liani, this is Manny. So let me just add a couple of things. Part of it, I think, is we're seeing some of the macro, as we talked about, right? That's impacted us in certain geographies around the world and that's been significant. The second thing we
componenttext: Tal Liani, this is Manny. So let me just add a couple of things. Part of it, I think, is we're seeing some of the macro, as we talked about, right? That's impacted us in certain geographies around the world and that's been significant. The second thing we have seen is some of the lumpiness in service provider business, which on certain quarters had been very, very solid, but this last quarter was down relative to other quarters. So it hasn't been 1 specific thing. It's actually been a series of things throughout the year that's continued to create that deceleration. But there's no question that there is also some pause, I think, in the market as these network transitions begin to occur, whether it be SDN and how SDN plays out in the enterprise, how cloud also plays out in the enterprise from a hybrid perspective, and in the service provider arena, how things like NFV play out and whether how quickly they move in those arenas. So I think, some of this is just caution on the customers as they redesign their new architectures, but what we're not seeing is any significant losses. We've looked at our win-loss data on an ongoing basis. So we think as we continue to further our technology solutions there, as the market continues to harden and adopt those new architectures, that we should see favorable second half of FY '16.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And does it increase your appetite to do some M&A and expand the addressable market? Or is it just a question of continued execution focused under same things? And I'm thinking kind of 3 years down the road, how do you want to see the company?
componenttext: And does it increase your appetite to do some M&A and expand the addressable market? Or is it just a question of continued execution focused under same things? And I'm thinking kind of 3 years down the road, how do you want to see the company?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I mean, the answer is yes to both of those, right. We're always looking at M&A from the perspective of looking at logical adjacencies, but it's got to be adjacencies that fit to our core footprint. We're pretty well-grounded on focusing on being a
componenttext: Yes, so I mean, the answer is yes to both of those, right. We're always looking at M&A from the perspective of looking at logical adjacencies, but it's got to be adjacencies that fit to our core footprint. We're pretty well-grounded on focusing on being application-centric and application-fluent, providing either user services on the user side of the proxy and or application services on the application side of the proxy. So as we can introduce M&A to enhance that portfolio as well as the roadmap, we will do that throughout the course of this coming year and future years. So it's something that we're aggressively looking at and will continue to look at. But it's got to be core to the business we do. We're not looking for an adjacency that doesn't give us the synergies that we have with our distribution, meaning our direct sales organization and our channels.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Jayson Noland of Baird.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Jayson Noland of Baird.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask on F Q1 guide and the statement around factoring a measure of continued uncertainty. Are you seeing less pipeline now relative to last year? Or is this simply just a function of being more conservative on close rates?
componenttext: I wanted to ask on F Q1 guide and the statement around factoring a measure of continued uncertainty. Are you seeing less pipeline now relative to last year? Or is this simply just a function of being more conservative on close rates?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, it's the latter. Pipeline -- when you look at total pipeline, affecting how that ebbs and flows, that can be deceiving. When we're looking at the factored pipeline, we feel pretty good about the business, but what -- not factored into how we
componenttext: Yes, I think, it's the latter. Pipeline -- when you look at total pipeline, affecting how that ebbs and flows, that can be deceiving. When we're looking at the factored pipeline, we feel pretty good about the business, but what -- not factored into how we give guidance. The latter, the issues that we highlighted with foreign currency impacting build decisions and timing of deals, some of the macro stuff that Manny alluded to where we saw some service provider deals slip, those kinds of things just make us want to be cautious in particular in our Q1.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, it's the same thing. We have really good fidelity via sales force of the pipeline. We've always had that discipline, and it's something that John's carrying throughout the organization. And we see that to be healthy, to be perfectly honest. So we
componenttext: I mean, it's the same thing. We have really good fidelity via sales force of the pipeline. We've always had that discipline, and it's something that John's carrying throughout the organization. And we see that to be healthy, to be perfectly honest. So we have good visibility with projects that are out there, some of them are longer-term projects, but definitely, we have good visibility to that, meaning the service provider tend to be longer-term projects. It's just about being a little bit more conservative on the close rates based on the uncertainties that we see, macro as well as currency fluctuations.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes sense. And then, a follow-up on service provider. It sounds -- is that Americas specific? And any additional color you can provide? Is that Tier 1? What type of use case? Has visibility change there specifically?
componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. And then, a follow-up on service provider. It sounds -- is that Americas specific? And any additional color you can provide? Is that Tier 1? What type of use case? Has visibility change there specifically?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Visibility has not changed. We still see good momentum across the 4 solution sets we provide out there. It just tends to be a much more project-oriented driven, so we had a couple of large deals over the course of Q2, Q3. Those are being absorbed by some
componenttext: Visibility has not changed. We still see good momentum across the 4 solution sets we provide out there. It just tends to be a much more project-oriented driven, so we had a couple of large deals over the course of Q2, Q3. Those are being absorbed by some of the service providers we anticipate additional repeat business as they tend to be healthy and happy customers.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Tim Long of BMO Capital.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Tim Long of BMO Capital.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to the product growth that's been decelerating a little bit, seeing some challenges there. You did talk -- I'm pretty sure you include software sales in that line, and obviously, those have been growing. As you mentioned a few times, t
componenttext: I wanted to go back to the product growth that's been decelerating a little bit, seeing some challenges there. You did talk -- I'm pretty sure you include software sales in that line, and obviously, those have been growing. As you mentioned a few times, there's some traction on the products. Could you talk just a little bit about the hardware component of that line? How much is that decelerating? What's driving that? Is that just saturation of the market? Is that just a pure cannibalization by the software element? Is this just going to be negative forever? Or is there something else going on, on the hardware component of the product sales?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, part of it is just the product life cycle that we see. I mean, we continue to see from our customers this concept of what we call hybrid application services architecture, which is a combination of both hardware and software. We don't see hardwar
componenttext: Yes. No, part of it is just the product life cycle that we see. I mean, we continue to see from our customers this concept of what we call hybrid application services architecture, which is a combination of both hardware and software. We don't see hardware sales deteriorating by any means. They're not accelerating in the traditional enterprise use cases that we see out there. Where you need higher network agility, which could be either in a software-defined architecture inside a private data center or where you're bursting or moving applications to the cloud, those tend to be software additions. So we're seeing that increase but a lot of that software that's increasing are new workloads. They're not the traditional workloads that we provided services for such as the traditional office applications or exchange applications or Oracle ERP systems. They tend to be now applications that are in the lines of businesses. Karl, is there anything you want to add to that?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to add -- I was just going to add, yes, we're not seeing deceleration in the hardware. I mean, for example, we're getting a lot of push right now on 100 gig interfaces, and those are coming here soon for us, but we're definitely seeing a sh
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to add -- I was just going to add, yes, we're not seeing deceleration in the hardware. I mean, for example, we're getting a lot of push right now on 100 gig interfaces, and those are coming here soon for us, but we're definitely seeing a shift in the last couple of quarters in terms of customers really wanting to adopt these much higher bandwidth interfaces which means they need the bigger, higher performance hardware to support those. It's just it's not something that works well moving to a cloud-type environment for those customers. And then, also, as Manny mentioned earlier in his script, we're working very aggressively on the appliance refresh, which, again, later next year -- or later this year, excuse me, we expect to start seeing -- rolling those platforms out. And those will bring in, again, significant new performance and capabilities, including things like 2 to 3x performance improvements, 100 gig interfaces, 40 gig, everything down the line being able to support our FPGA-based architecture right down to the lowest cost platform. So we'll be bringing on a lot of new things with those platforms and we expect good demand when they do show up.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're also -- just to add one last point there is we're also doing performance improvements on our virtual addition. So it's not just the hardware that you see create performance. Across the suite of products, you'll see us continue to provide industry-le
componenttext: We're also -- just to add one last point there is we're also doing performance improvements on our virtual addition. So it's not just the hardware that you see create performance. Across the suite of products, you'll see us continue to provide industry-leading performance.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, in fact, I should mention, this is public, but we did a demo of 40-gig VE with our partner, Intel, at Intel IDF here earlier this year, and we expect to be able to achieve much higher performance levels going into next year. It was just demo but it j
componenttext: Yes, in fact, I should mention, this is public, but we did a demo of 40-gig VE with our partner, Intel, at Intel IDF here earlier this year, and we expect to be able to achieve much higher performance levels going into next year. It was just demo but it just kind of shows we're able to take our software.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our last question is from the line of Simon Leopold of Raymond James.
componenttext: And our last question is from the line of Simon Leopold of Raymond James.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things that I wanted to ask about. One was you were kind enough to offer commentary about operating margin trends through fiscal '16, and it sounds like very similar to the pattern you've seen in the past, mid-30s in the first half of the year, high 3
componenttext: Two things that I wanted to ask about. One was you were kind enough to offer commentary about operating margin trends through fiscal '16, and it sounds like very similar to the pattern you've seen in the past, mid-30s in the first half of the year, high 30s in the second half. I'm just wondering if you could talk about the increasing mix of software content and more of a software orientation to the business? Why we shouldn't be seeing more year-over-year improvement in the operating margin? So that's the first thing I wanted to ask. The second one is your service provider business, I appreciate, is lumpy and certainly service provider spending is difficult. But it's been, I guess, a little while since you talked about the opportunities around diameter and routing and wireless. I just like to see if we can get an update of where you see that opportunity in the coming number of quarters?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, do you want to take the operating margin trends?
componenttext: John, do you want to take the operating margin trends?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And as you've highlighted, for the last 3 years, we've basically laid out that because of the seasonality of our business and our desire to keep investing and not slow down the momentum we have in the first half, we target mid-30s, growing in the lat
componenttext: Yes. And as you've highlighted, for the last 3 years, we've basically laid out that because of the seasonality of our business and our desire to keep investing and not slow down the momentum we have in the first half, we target mid-30s, growing in the latter half, and you're absolutely right. Some of the things we've been able to do over the last year that we look at, we introduced Silverline and that came in the cost of some of the margins, we put that into the gross margin, so building up these socks that we build out. And we were able to do that and maintain our gross margin. And as we've long stated, our strategy is to leverage the gross margin to invest in the business where we think it will help drive revenue. If we go back 2 years ago, we said we wanted to make an investment in consulting, which we did. Now we were able to do that and maintain margin, and we see those consultants driving business for us. So that's kind of how we've executed and it's working for us and we want to continue that. And as always, with our disciplined and management approach, we'll watch it and adjust as we need to, but that's how we want to see it lay out.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And to answer the second part and first part of the business, there are 4 primary solutions you provide to service provider market. One is Gi LAN services. We're seeing nice growth on that. I commented on that. Second is security which we saw strong momen
componenttext: And to answer the second part and first part of the business, there are 4 primary solutions you provide to service provider market. One is Gi LAN services. We're seeing nice growth on that. I commented on that. Second is security which we saw strong momentum throughout the course of the year with specifically U.S. carriers. And the third is NFE, which is although early proof of concept. The fourth one is actually traffics for solution perspective. On that one, we're still seeing -- we're seeing relatively modest revenue, to be honest. And in overall scheme of things of what we anticipate that -- as that traffic grows, or signaling grows over the course of a couple of -- over the next couple of years here as 4G continues to be deployed and hopefully 5G in the future. And we're -- of course, where we've deployed that technology, we're seeing great project rollouts and happy customers, so we anticipate future business.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Karl. I'll just add a couple of points to that real quick is that also on BIG-IP, we handle a significant amount of signaling traffic. So we help scale SIP and diameter and other aspects of the control plane [indiscernible] if we would fit. A
componenttext: Yes, this is Karl. I'll just add a couple of points to that real quick is that also on BIG-IP, we handle a significant amount of signaling traffic. So we help scale SIP and diameter and other aspects of the control plane [indiscernible] if we would fit. And again, as Manny mentioned, our security services, we're seeing good adoption at major Tier 1 carriers throughout the world, including MSOs. It's just it takes time for them to install, integrate and then expand our infrastructure with those. And so we're still kind of on that side of the curve right now. But definitely good feedback, definitely have these things in full production moving forward.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you again for joining us on today's call. We hope to see many of you at our Analyst Day on November 12 in New York, at the New York Hilton Midtown. So until then, we have good week and talk to you later.
componenttext: Well, thank you again for joining us on today's call. We hope to see many of you at our Analyst Day on November 12 in New York, at the New York Hilton Midtown. So until then, we have good week and talk to you later.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
